record.text:
And, to be clear here, I'm not saying "We should use ChatGPT for grammar check."

I just mean hypothetically such a tool COULD potentially be created in a way that is useful to SOMEONE.

But I have a hard time understanding why published author Cory Doctorow needs an LLM grammar check.

An LLM would potentially have sufficiently better grammar checking compared to conventional grammar check.

That might be a useful tool for an English learner or maybe(?) someone with a disability of some kind (after a stroke or something?) but for him it seems like making soup in a cement mixer.

record.text: OpenAI, the maker of the popular AI chatbot ChatGPT, has removed “safely” from its mission statement, which now reads “to ensure that artificial general intelligence benefits all of humanity.” This change occurred as the company transformed from a nonprofit organization to a for-profit business,…

external.description: OpenAI, the maker of the popular AI chatbot, has made significant changes to its mission statement, removing the word "safely" from its goal to benefit humanity. This shift in focus has raised concerns about the company's priorities, particularly in light of several lawsuits related to the safety of its products. OpenAI was founded as a nonprofit scientific research lab in 2015, with the original purpose of benefiting society by making its findings public and royalty-free.
external.title: OpenAI, the maker of the popular AI chatbot ChatGPT, has removed “safely” from its mission statement, which now reads “to ensure that artificial general intelligence benefits all of humanity.” This change occurred as the company transformed from a nonprofit organization to a for-profit business, with a focus on generating financial returns, and currently faces several lawsuits related to the safety of its products. OpenAI’s original mission statement, filed with the IRS in 2022, aimed to build artificial intelligence that “safely benefits humanity, unconstrained by a need to generate financial return.” The company’s restructuring, which includes the creation of a nonprofit foundation and a for-profit public benefit corporation, has raised concerns about its commitment to safety and the potential for conflicts of interest. Despite the changes, OpenAI’s website still mentions safety as a key aspect of its mission, stating that it requires “simultaneously advancing AI’s capability, safety, and positive impact in the world.” The company’s new structure, which includes a safety and security committee on the OpenAI Foundation board, is designed to promote safety, but the lack of explicit reference to safety in the mission statement may make it difficult to hold the boards accountable.

NEW‼️ For the forthcoming Pandemic Agreement travaux préparatoires edited by @alexandraphelan.bsky.social, we did a deep dive on how experts and evidence shaped the negotiations. What we found is a microcosm of global health: limited time, high stakes, and familiar shady actors like Big Pharma. (1/3)

images.alt:
Expert engagement and evidence use in treaty negotiations
24 Pages Posted:
Anna Bezruki
affiliation not provided to SSRN

Chloe Batie
Yale University

Colin Carlson
Yale University

Date Written: February 10, 2026

Abstract
Science-and evidence-based decision-making are core values in global health, but in multilateral processes, they often take a backseat to politics. The Pandemic Agreement requires Parties to use "the best available science and evidence as the basis for public health decisions for pandemic prevention, preparedness and response," but is the treaty itself evidence-based? In this chapter, we trace how scientific and technical evidence were introduced into the Intergovernmental Negotiating Body. External experts were a key source of advice, especially on legal issues, but they were mostly excluded from the negotiations. Over time, Member States began to treat Relevant Stakeholders as a secondary source of technical expertise, introducing potential conflicts of interest into the process. In the end, scientists and stakeholders successfully leveraged scientific authority to facilitate the incorporation of One Health approach to pandemic prevention (Articles 4 and 5)-but otherwise, the treaty was shaped more by politics and pragmatism than by science. Moving forward, the Conference of Parties will be an opportunity for Member States to establish formal channels for scientific evidence synthesis and engagement-or to preserve a status quo that falls substantially behind evidence-based global governance in other areas.

Keywords: Citation networks, evidence-based policy, One Health, Pandemic Agreement, scientometrics, World Health Organization

Figure 1. Evidence use in the WHO Pandemic Agreement negotiations: (A) by user type
and evidence type; and (B) by individual users and documents. Flows are proportional to
the number of instances. In panel B, shaded flows represent self-citations by individual
contributors (purple) or by organizations (red).

Figure 2. Evidence use networks connecting documents (red) and users (blue). Edge width
and node size is proportional to the number of references made. For visual clarity, only the
most influential nodes are labeled. Layout is based on network connections and readability,
and does not necessarily reflect node properties (e.g., centrality).

This is why we don't let LLMs near any @epic-biodiversity.org code.

record.text:
Taking a course on ChatGPT. The current project example is organizing a birthday party for an 8-year old. Among the parameters: a $1000 budget.

Yes, I just shouted at my monitor “Who TF spends $1,000 on a kid’s birthday?!”

The courseware I just bought thinks my email addy is not valid; I can’t log in. Submitted a ticket to support; support tech suggested I *log in* and try a few things.

“So, your advice for the email address your system won’t allow is… to log in using the email address your software won’t allow?”

Getting a huge kick out of this job application form. The developers allowed this skill picker control to list EVERYTHING, so… I’m up to the “M’s” now. This is going to be a treat for anyone who has to read through it.
Ok I have never heard of pesto hummus but now I need some.
I get so sick and tired of seeing “I asked chatGPT if—“ all over the tl. The hallucination machine isn’t a fucking search engine.

Yeah it’s really easy. I honestly just eyeball everything. Some recipes call for more olive oil, but there are oil free recipes too. I use a little oil and if it needs more liquid, I’ll add a couple ice cubes into the food processor.

So, if we start with the assumption that Cory's usage = Meta's training data, sure. But even then, it's not as simple as the OP said. It's not just "man up & use AI, wuss." He was clearly attempting (however badly) to work within Open Source. And you're pointing out the clear problems.

I'm not saying it's the only one. I'm saying that, as you're demonstrating here, there are many, many layers. I cannot count out the training sources. I don't buy your assumption "no one can train." That's just not true.

there's lots of weird, unsupported claims in this article, but the one that really catches my eye is this supposed conflict between a "philosophical definition" and an "empirical description"

this more than anything makes the author suspect - there is nothing strange about the view presented here

images.alt:
On the other hand, it’s a bit less strange if you consider it as an example of an intellectual war that’s escaping into the world from academia.

Here Bender is again the way to understanding.

Her view of AI is based on a firm belief about the nature of knowledge that comes from her work in linguistics. “The language modeling task, because it only uses form as training data, cannot in principle lead to learning of meaning,” she writes in one paper, meaning, basically, that because LLMs are disembodied, they cannot connect words to the things in the world they describe — which is a problem, since connecting words to things is the essence of meaning. The key term in that claim is “in principle.” It means that no amount of improvement in LLM ability could ever change the claim, and indeed, as LLMs have improved, Bender has shown little sign of altering her view.

This description of how AI works is in other words more a philosophical definition than an empirical description. That’s why the main energy of her work lately is to reframe — to drag things from process and output back to philosophy. That’s why “understanding” becomes “parroting,” “neural networks” become “mathy maths,” “LLMs” become “synthetic text extruding machines.” She who best changes the terms wins the debate is the approach, and Bender has in many ways done just that. (Of course, that “Can mathy maths help us make better decisions?” is a perfectly cogent question, to which the answer is almost certainly yes, shows the limits of this approach.)

Bender is entitled to her philosophy. She knows what she’s committing to and what risks she’s running. And, to be fair, she doesn’t think that AI is always useless. “There are applications of machine learning that are well scoped,” she’s written. “These include such everyday things as spell-checkers.” But, for the most part, the people who parrot the parrots hypothesis thirdhand don’t know this. They don’t know they’ve signed up in a long-running philosophical war. They think they are talking about capabilities, about scientific measurement. And that mismatch is leading them into worrying places.

The world feels different now. Not worse, not better, just unpredictable. News cycles accelerate. Economies wobble. AI innovations create promise and fear at the same time. Climate shocks…

external.description: The world feels different now. Not worse, not better, just unpredictable. News cycles accelerate. Economies wobble. AI innovations create promise and fear at the same time. Climate shocks arrive without warning. Social systems fracture, trust erodes, and yet life goes on. Many people feel a persistent tension they can’t name. They wake up anxious, scroll for answers, and find none. It is a subtle, gnawing stress: the sense that the ground beneath society is shifting, even if it is invisible to the casual observer.

external.description: For most of modern history, stability was the goal. People chose careers for security. Companies built systems for efficiency. Governments promised predictability. Education prepared individuals for a world that would not change too fast. Stability meant safety, progress, and control. But something has shifted. Quietly, almost invisibly, stability stopped being reliable. Many people feel this before they can articulate it. The job that once felt safe now feels temporary.

🎶 Titelsong 》„Savage“ von Asaka  

🎙️ Charaktere & Cast (Japanisch)
»Riddle« von Junya Enoki
»Norn« von Azusa Tadokoro

Mit einem ersten Trailer gab es neue Einblicke in »The Great Sage Riddle's Time Reversal« sowie ein Vorgeschmack auf den Titelsong »Savage« von Asaka. Der Light-Anime startet am 1. April im japanischen TV. Zudem stellte man zwei Mitglieder des japanischen Sprechercasts offiziell vor.

📜 Beschreibung 》
Riddle hat durch die mysteriöse Organisation „Box of Malice“ alles verloren: seine Freunde und sogar die ganze Welt. Am Ende seiner Hoffnungslosigkeit kommt ihm ein letzter Gedanke: Was, wenn er in die Zeit vor der Katastrophe zurückkehren könnte? Nach tausend Jahren gelingt ihm tatsächlich die Zeitumkehr. Mit einem jungen Körper, aber tausend Jahren Wissen, schwört er: Diesmal wird er sie stoppen.

The hype phase is over. Investors want real returns.

AI coding agents are like very fast interns who never learn from mistakes. If you can spot a bad pattern in 10 seconds, the agent is 10x leverage. If you can't, you're shipping bugs at scale. The verification bottleneck is real—reading AI code often takes as long as writing it yourself
AI coding agents are multipliers, not replacements. Experts get 10x output, juniors get messy codebases they can't maintain. The skill gap doesn't shrink — it gets expressed differently.

value.text: Tesla has to pay historical $243 million judgement over Autopilot crash, judge says

external.description:
A federal judge has rejected Tesla’s bid to overturn a $243 million jury verdict over a fatal 2019 Autopilot crash in Florida, dealing a significant blow to the automaker’s legal strategy as it faces a growing wave of lawsuits tied to its driver-assistance technology.



U.S. District Judge Beth Bloom in Miami ruled that the evidence at trial “more than supported” the verdict and that Tesla raised no new arguments to justify setting it aside. The ruling, made public on Friday, means Tesla’s last hope to avoid paying the massive judgment at the trial court level has been exhausted.

 more…
external.title: Tesla has to pay historical $243 million judgement over Autopilot crash, judge says
